Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech, a fundamental democratic principle.
It creates a discriminatory system dividing citizens into two classes: those who can spread information freely and ordinary citizens who cannot.
Excessive fines will lead digital platforms to impose stricter restrictions on speech.
Determining truth is complex and ever-changing, making it difficult to legislate against misinformation accurately.
The bill's scope includes misleading or deceptive information, further eroding free speech.
Delegating legislative power to private entities is unconstitutional and undermines democratic processes.
The bill assumes government and accredited institutions have the final say on truth, disregarding ordinary Australians' viewpoints.
Notable Quotes: This bill reflects a lack of respect for the freedom of speech that is fundamental to our democracy.
The excessive fines outlined in this bill will undeniably lead digital platforms to impose stricter restrictions on freedom of speech.
It is an impossible task to accurately determine what is true or untrue, as new information constantly emerges contradicting previously accepted facts.
The bill disempowers ordinary people by asserting that their viewpoints are more likely to cause harm than those of the Government or its accredited journalists and educators.
